summary.section: 1.0 Minutes: July 11th meeting and public hearing
summary.summary:
- Meeting begins with a quorum present
- First item on the agenda is to review the minutes from previous meetings
- Martin has a question about an unfamiliar name in the minutes
- Schwartz clarifies the name as Daniel Tompkins, who spoke about the "Mars" project
- Revane jokes about Jim's phone being on silent
- Revane moves to approve the minutes, Crandall seconds, and all approve
- Martin asks for more information about Daniel Tompkins

summary.section: 2.1 Scott Nazarian/Carlson & Bowen â€“ TM 14-138 and 14-124, proposed annexation or lot line adjustment
summary.summary:
- Scott Nazarian and his neighbors are interested in either doing an annexation or a lot line adjustment in LAE.
- Both parties need sign off from their mortgage companies before proceeding.
- There is a potential issue with a driveway on one of the lots, which may be resolved through a land trade.
- Enforcing the mortgage problem and obtaining approval is important to avoid foreclosure issues.
- Douglas shares a personal experience with a similar situation and the need to fix a deed issue.
- The discussion focuses on the potential non-conformity of the lots and the impact of making them smaller.
- The issue of non-conformity in LAE is raised and discussed.
- The conversation moves on to the next topic.

- Florence sent out two draft documents for LUO 307 and the Driveway Permit Application and is seeking feedback
- Schwartz suggests identifying whether the driveway is temporary or permanent on the form
- Kluk suggests adding "check all that apply" instead of "check the appropriate box" on the form
- Discussion about ownership and responsibility within the right of way
- Suggestions to clarify terminology and improve the form
- Martin suggests using arrows to clarify the extent of the right of way
- Discussion about the terms "driveway access" and "curb cut"
- Suggestions to improve the form, including adding applicant's address and phone number
- Discussion about the distinction between roadway and right of way
- Suggestions to improve the form, including clarifying when Part I and Part II are needed and adding a $30 filing fee
- Discussion about the definition of driveway access and curb cut
- Suggestions to improve the form, including clarifying regulations for private roads
- Revane provides information on road maintenance responsibilities for private roads
- Discussion about making changes to the proposed LUO 307.2
- Martin suggests adding "if applicable" to clarify when Part II approval is needed
- Kluk suggests adding "or alteration" to clarify when approval is needed for driveway construction

summary.section: 3.1 Town Center Vision project, parking and access for town buildings, planning for Library adjacent property
summary.summary:
- Crandall has been meeting with the Select Board to discuss the access and parking for Town Hall, in addition to the library and community garden projects.
- The long stairway leading up from the lower parking for Town Hall has been dropped due to controversy.
- The library shed is in poor condition and will be rebuilt at a smaller size on the existing concrete pad.
- Estimates for the shed will be provided by Mike Carter and Reese Ferry.
- The shed will have a combination padlock for security.
- DPW will turn the soil in the garden area this fall for planting next spring.
- The approximate cost for the shed is between $15,000 and $20,000.
- The plan for Town Hall parking and access does not worsen the current egress situation and creating a new egress road is not feasible due to state regulations.
- Henniker Septic will assess the load bearing capabilities of the leach field behind Town Hall to potentially expand the rear parking.
- The grassy area in front of Town Hall will be expanded, but parking will be prohibited.
- The possibility of expanding the lot behind Town Hall is being explored, but plans were not available at the meeting.
- Tighter parking spaces and smaller, curved cement blocks are being considered to allow for more vehicles to fit in the space.

- Crandall believes that the Master Plan is still a placeholder.
- Douglas agrees with Crandall's statement.

- Crandall asks about any updates from the ZBA.
- Florence responds that there were no ZBA hearings in July.
- No property owner requested a variance during that time.

- Kluk is interested in updates on the NASA proposal and the timeline for next steps.
- Revane discusses the recent determination of the location for the access road and trail, as well as the involvement of environmental experts and neighboring landowners.
- Crandall asks about public input in the process, and Revane assures that it will be incorporated.
- Schwartz asks about wetlands crossings and forestry plans, and Revane provides information on the changes in the landscape and the involvement of a forester.
- Crandall asks about funding, and Revane explains that there is currently no funding as there are no immediate plans.
- Kluk suggests involving NH NEMBA for constructing trails, and Revane discusses the restrictions and options for activities on the property.
- Crandall mentions that ATVs cannot be kept off the property, and Revane acknowledges this.
- Schwartz asks about the connection to Wild Acre, and Revane explains the trail system and the idea of providing designated areas for ATVs to minimize their roaming.

- There is a merger on the agenda for Fluery, but paperwork is not available for discussion
- Paperwork is available for a merger between Kelly and Matthew Lannon to merge lots 14-76 and 14-75 on Stowell Road
- The new lot size will be 2.65 acres
- Kelly and Matthew Lannon have provided the necessary fee and deeds
- Douglas asks if a surveyor is needed, but it is confirmed that they do not need one
- Douglas makes a motion to accept the merger as presented, which is seconded by Schwartz
- All members in attendance vote in favor
- The group proceeds to sign and date the paperwork

transcription.title: 2.1 Scott Nazarian/Carlson & Bowen â€“ TM 14-138 and 14-124, proposed annexation or lot line adjustment

transcription.speaker: Crandall
transcription.speech: The new business is a proposed annexation.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech:
Scott Nazarian and his neighbor Carlson and Bowen are interested in either doing an annexation or a lot line adjustment in LAE. Unfortunately, they are unable to attend tonight. I spoke to Peter Mellon, who was contacted by Scott about the plan that was done for Carlson and Bowen over a year ago. The issue we are facing is that both of us need sign off from our mortgage companies before proceeding, as we both have mortgages and will be trading land. 

In Hillsboro, he told me that there has been a problem before, so he simply informed me about it. He mentioned that they might choose to follow through with it after resolving the issue, or they might attempt to do it beforehand. However, it is important to note that obtaining sign off is necessary.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: You're going to make the lots smaller?

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: I believe that the lots are of a good size, but there might be a problem with a driveway on one of them. They are considering trading land so that the issue can be resolved, and it seems like Scott was planning to give them a portion of that land.

transcription.speaker: Crandall
transcription.speech: Why are we being asked to enforce the mortgage problem and verify if it has been approved? Why would we need to ask them to do so?

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: If I approve something and someone ends up getting foreclosed on, it becomes a major issue with the mortgage companies.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: In 1975, I experienced a situation where my driveway or house was not on my property, which caused a problem with the bank. Despite it being there for 40 years, they were unhappy about it. The deed was messed up, but I had to fix it on my own. And I did manage to straighten it out.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: Adverse possession?

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: No, they wouldn't allow me to do that. However, I had to go through the planning board in order to proceed. I viewed it as a friendly endeavor, as I took a quarter acre lot and transformed it into a third of an acre. This was done because everyone believed their lot line was located here, when in fact it was there. Consequently, I acquired the additional land for a mere dollar, all in a spirit of friendliness.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: In the case before us now, is a non-conforming lot going to be made more or less conforming?

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I was just going to ask the same question.

transcription.speaker: Ravane
transcription.speech: Nazarian owns 14-138, which was made into a weird shape when we merged a 0.16 acre lot to make a 2.16 acre lot a while back. Carlson and Bowen own 14-124, also 2.16 acres. I think Nazarian is trying to give them those 0.16 acres, cutting the property line straight. So that's going to make the Nazarian lot smaller and less conforming. It's gonna take a 2.16 acre lot and drop it to one point something. So how do you make a lot smaller?

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: But weren't all those lots approved previously as half-acre lots?

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: Once they were deeded, they were deeded. They're all different sizes.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: I thought they got 400 lots out of that.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: Well, there are all different lot sizes. You can't make a lot smaller.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: It looks like they both have double lots. We'll have to see what he presents to us.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: None of them are conforming at 4 acres.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: I don't know how to address the issue of non-conformity in LAE. Personally, I have experience with this matter on Valley Road. In our community, we didn't allow someone to freely move between two places because it seemed to promote more non-conforming behavior.

transcription.speaker: Crandall
transcription.speech: Moving on ...

transcription.speaker: Crandall
transcription.speech: Moving on to driveway regulations. I thought we had a very good working session.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Yesterday evening, I sent out two draft documents via email. One was for LUO 307 and the other was for the Driveway Permit Application. I'm seeking suggestions from anyone regarding any errors, omissions, or any other feedback on these drafts.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: We need to identify whether the driveway is temporary or permanent, either on the diagram or elsewhere.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I added the "temporary" checkbox we spoke of. Was that not enough, do you think?

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: It's at the bottom of the blue section. There's a checkbox that says "temporary driveway".

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: I think the form should ask first: is the driveway temporary or permanent? Then, the applicant can check the other boxes as appropriate.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: So two major categories: temporary and permanent?

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: Agreed. Then the applicant can check off the other categories: new construction, alteration and so on.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Isn't logging by definition temporary?

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: No. Logging can be permanent too.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: I performed some logging work, and during that time, Ed contacted me to discuss whether I preferred a permanent or temporary arrangement. I expressed my preference for it to be made permanent, as I intend to return to construct a driveway in the future.

transcription.speaker: Crandall
transcription.speech: The same circumstances applied to me.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: I really don't want to be the one who has to put the stonewall back. If it's only meant to be temporary, then it's your responsibility to restore the wall. Honestly, I can't even lift those heavy rocks, so it's impossible for me to do it.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: As I was going through it, I found myself questioning whether we really need to say "check the appropriate box."

transcription.speaker: All
transcription.speech: Yes, we do.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I believe that if we need those words, then it should be stated as "check all that apply."

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Agreed, I will make that change.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: Do we need the checkbox "landscape within the right of way"?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I copied that from the Atkinson application form. I didn't make it up.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: Okay, yes. I believe that it all comes down to whether I am going to have an impact by doing landscaping in the right way. Will my actions as a landscaper make a difference?

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: I know where this has happened.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: Yes, on Jean Kluk's road.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: Indeed, right next to me.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: No, I'm referring to a  person who wanted to place a series of large rocks on a corner of Valley Road to enhance the area. Surprisingly, DPW agreed to it, saying it was okay to do so. This meant that he could also landscape within the right of way, including the fence and everything else.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: Agreed. There have been other cases where a homeowner has erected a fence in the right-of-way.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I noticed that there are additional checkboxes on the first page. I wondered if I should add "check all the options that apply" in that section. At first glance, it appeared clear to me what needed to be done.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: Why don't we change the bullets the boxes?

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I believe that's a problem with Word, or whatever software we have on our computers.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: The two documents, the LUO 307 draft and the Driveway Permit Application form are both Google Documents. You should see checkboxes when you view them.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: I approved of the instructions you added above the driveway diagram.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Good. I thought those were the words we agreed upon.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: There should be some words that say "check all that apply".

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Agreed. I will add that underneath the diagram.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I am currently working on a schematic for a roadway and lot boundary. I must admit, I am not very experienced with roads, so I am trying my best to figure it out. I have been looking at the subdivision regulations, specifically the schematics provided, but I couldn't find any information regarding the lot boundary. The schematics only show the roadway and the dotted line representing the right of way.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: I thought that the right way line is the lot boundary?

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: No.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: It had better be.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: The right of way is an area, not a line. That's what I intended to represent in the diagram.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: You don't own beyond the right of way. You *cannot* own beyond the right of way.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: The right of way is the area from the stonewall to the pavement. It is not part of the lot and not the property of the owner of the lot.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Agreed. That's why I drew it the way I did in the diagram.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: The problem I'm facing is that the right way does not necessarily take up the full width. It's like this for both corners of my lot that are near the road. However, what about a cross street? It's the same situation, as they are right by the roadway. I live in a newer subdivision, and the culvert that was put in is eight feet onto our property from the edge of the road. This is why I always thought it was approved, but it shouldn't have been. The driveway culvert was installed in 1991, which is now a concern for the town if it gets blocked. Although it is technically on my property based on where my property stakes are, the town has an easement or right of way. This means they can trim or cut down trees that are theoretically on my property but within the right of way. Utility companies have the same authority, and the town can even be held responsible for not maintaining or removing dead trees in that right of way.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I fail to understand how one can claim ownership over something in the right of way. The concept of owning anything within the right of way seems perplexing to me, as it is the town, state, or private development that holds ownership over it.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: I'd be interested in seeing the Kluk property plan

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: You have the legal option to use that piece of property even though you don't own it.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: If the town or the state wanted to widen the road, they have the authority to extend it up to my property line. In other words, they could pave the road all the way up to the lot line that belongs to me.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: If they wanted to go further than that, they could take part of the property by eminent domain, but that's a separate issue.

transcription.speaker: Speaker 1
transcription.speech: On the diagram, I labeled that strip of land "right of way" because that's where the proposed LUO 307.1 governs.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: I don't know if it needs to be as wide.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I drew it as wide as I did because I believed that the flare and the culvert would be the focal points of the interesting events. It is important to note that nothing can be drawn in the roadway itself.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: I think the roadway should have a solid line at the edge, while the right-of-way should have a dotted line.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: The right of way is not represented as a line on my diagram, but rather as a strip of land.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: Why not change the wording to "right of way *area*" and "roadway *surface*". That would clarify matters.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Agreed, that makes a big difference.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: I am trying to determine if the roadway is made of compacted gravel or not, specifically focusing on the area where your tires might go off into the ditch line. The concern is mainly related to water flow and runoff, particularly in the area before your property where the Department of Public Works is most concerned.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I believe that we reached a consensus on the fact that in about 90% of the cases, the diagram in the lot area will simply consist of a 50-foot straight line. This line would be 12 feet wide and extend directly to the house. Essentially, this arrangement would be applicable to almost all scenarios. Personally, I am quite fond of these new terms, and I will make the necessary adjustments accordingly.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I think those terms are easy to get your head around.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: I must admit that I completely misread this. Initially, I mistakenly interpreted the solid line as indicating the boundary of a lot, while perceiving the dotted line as representing the right of way. Furthermore, I mistakenly believed that the bottom of the drawing denoted the location of the road.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I believe that annotating the area and surface helps clarify the distinction. A strip of land is indeed a strip of land, just like the roadway is also a strip of land. Therefore, we will change the label to "roadway surface".

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: If I want to put in a driveway, I would start by drawing a line from the edge of the roadway to my property. I measure the distance and it turns out to be 50 feet. I plan to have a 20-foot driveway. However, the Department of Public Works suggests installing a 12-inch culvert in this area.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I want to emphasize that the right of way is not a line, but instead an area, a strip of land.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: I don't like this drawing at all. Instead, I think the roadway should be drawn with a cross hatch, or something like it.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I appreciate the fact that, according to its definition, the diagram does not include any markings on the roadway. It seems that one aspect that might be causing confusion is the typical depiction of a roadway with the right of way area and lots on both sides. However, it's important to note that such elements are not applicable in the context of a driveway diagram.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: As a suggestion in order to clarify this point, why not draw up and down arrows, above and below the "right of way" label to emphasize its extent?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I agree with all those suggestions and I will make appropriate changes.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I have some additional suggestions. First, the form just asks for "address" but I believe it should be explicit, and ask for "applicant's address". Second, the form should ask for the applicant's phone number.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I deliberately dropped the phone number because I felt that the existing form asked for excessive information. In my opinion, having a phone is not necessary for the task of building a driveway.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I have a different opinion on this matter. In my view, it is highly beneficial for the applicant to be easily reachable, and this can prove to be quite challenging without a phone number.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Agreed. I will change the form to request "applicant address" and "phone".

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: When it comes to "location," I believe that all I need is the street address of the property where the driveway is constructed, along with the tax map and lot numbers. Fortunately, these can be easily obtained by anyone through our online maps.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Agreed. I will make that change also.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: Finally, I believe that it must be the *owner* not the *applicant* who signs the form. We've actually had a person who was leasing a property tried to get a driveway permit

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech:
Agreed. I will make that change also. 

I had an issue of my own when I drafted the form. Specifically, I intended to write "driveway access _slash_ curb cut," which is what we ultimately ended up with. However, upon seeing it written down, it appeared to me as if we were unsure of what to actually call it. We combined these two terms with a slash in between. Now, I'm not suggesting that we decide on a specific name for it right now, as we have ample time to make adjustments. However, I want to clarify that I did not like how it looked once I put it on paper.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: Well, it looks fine with a space between and the term is used many times between the two documents, the LUO 307 draft and the Driveway Permit Application.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: Why is a $30 payment required?

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: For the Driveway Permit Application.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: So I must enclose the $30 filing fee when I sign the form?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Yes, I admit that I simply copied it directly from what we currently do. I didn't come up with it myself, to be honest. I just replicated the wording we already have. I'm curious to know if you have any suggestions for improvement.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: Let's return to the subject of "driveway access slash curb cut".

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: To me, it seemed as if we were randomly combining two words or terms without a clear idea of what we wanted to name it.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: In the manual "Knowing the Territory," it is stated that driveway entrances, exits, and other activities commonly referred to as curb cuts are mentioned. The manual puts the term "curb cuts" in quotation marks. Furthermore, they refer to the maintenance of private driveway connections as "driveway connections." Interestingly, other sources have labeled them as "driveway access."

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: I like the phrase "driveway connection".

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: Did you copy questions 1 through 5 on page 3 of the application from the existing form?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: No. I added number 1 after our working session. That's the requirement to flag and stake the driveway location and extent for the purposes of site inspection.

transcription.speaker: Schwartz
transcription.speech: Do you think we need to state somewhere that this is a two part application?

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: Perhaps a subtitle under the main Driveway Permit Application title that reads "Part I and Part II" would work.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: One issue is that Part I is not applicable if you're building a driveway on Route 31, for example,

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: I think the subtitle as I described earlier will work. The LUO spells out when you need Part I and when you need Part II.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Also, there's an information box on top of page 3, that's Part I, that tells you when you need that page completed, and a similar information box on top of page 4 for Part II.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: Regarding that information box on top of page 3, I don't see where it tells you that it is not needed if your driveway access is to a State-maintained highway.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I worry that the more words we use, even as good-faith explanations, the less people will read them.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: How about instead just inserting the phrase "instead of the Town permit" when a State permit is required?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I like that idea very much.

transcription.speaker: Douglas
transcription.speech: As this is a legal document, how about "in _lieu_ of ..."?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: We speak American in Washington, Fred, not French! Although, if we were to be strictly legal, perhaps we should use Latin?

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: When it comes to the issue of "driveway access / curb cuts," I believe it would be beneficial to consider the approach outlined in the _Knowing the Territory_ manual. In this case, I suggest using the phrase "driveway access 'curb cut'."

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: That might work once, maybe twice, but we need to use the phrase multiple times and I think that construction will start to look weird.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: Use the "definitions" section of the LUO to make the statement just once.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech:
I have been considering the idea of having two separate definitions for driveway access and curb cut. I believe that curb cut is often used interchangeably with driveway access. However, this approach raises the question of which terms to use for the remaining parts of the definition.

One issue is that we don't have any actual "curbs" in Washington, and "curb cuts" is a Big City term.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: While we are talking about the definitions, why are Class IV roads not mentioned?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: There are no Class IV roads in Washington. Only 20-30 towns have Class IV roads, and they're all enumerated in the relevant RSA. All Town roads are either Class V or Class VI.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: I thought Class V was summer maintenance only?

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: That's not so. Some are, but that's not a characteristic of Class V.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: It is interesting to note that part of East Washington Road is Class II, but it is not State-maintained. That's the part from the junction of Bradford Springs Road to the Hillsboro line. Similarly, Bradford Springs Road is also Class II. Also, the Pillsbury access road is Class III.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: Why are we why are we regulating Private Road?

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: We want to regulate the driveway, specifically the portion that is on the owner's lot, regardless of whether it connects to a private road, town road, or a state-maintained highway. This regulation is necessary for the sake of health and safety, as well as for all the other reasons we regulate various aspects in the LUO.

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: The only remaining question to my mind is whether we are going to propose LUO 307 such that it governs driveway access to private roads.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I find it possible that there may be controversy surrounding the piece we have chosen to include. However, I am uncertain about our decision. Did we actually decide to include it? I recall us leaving the working session with the understanding that we would continue, even though it was not cast in concrete. We believed we had the authority to regulate the curb cut on a private road.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech: During our working session, I researched NHMA online. The Town LUO governs the properties in private developments as they have all adopted our land use ordinance. transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: I think it is beyond the ability of the seven of us present this evening to answer that question now. We should continue wit the assumption that LUO 307.1 will govern private roads until we get feedback from the public at the Public Hearing next February.

transcription.speaker: Revane
transcription.speech:
I have studied the relevant RSA concerning road maintenance. As of 2019 it falls 100% on the residents of the road.  

The RSA states: in the absence of an Express agreement or requirement governing maintenance of a private road when more than one residential owner enjoys a common benefit each residential owner shall contribute equitably to the reasonable cost of maintaining the road and shall have the right to bring a civil action to enforce the requirements of this paragraph.

That's the new state RSA that all the associations have a hard time with. Because they all want money from these private road maintenance, but they're commingling it with their other dues and they can't it's only can be used for road maintenance.

transcription.speaker: Martin
transcription.speech: Turning to the proposed LUO 307.2,  there's a statement that says prior to construction, Part II of the application must be approved. Should we say "if applicable"?

transcription.speaker: Kluk
transcription.speech: Instead of merely saying "driveway  construction", we should say "driveway construction _or alteration_". Otherwise, the instructions read as if approval is only needed when a new driveway us built.

transcription.speaker: Florence
transcription.speech: Agreed. I will  make all of these changes in in the next few days and then send revised drafts to the Board.
